vision_json.prompt_sent:
Extract ONLY publication metadata from these academic paper pages.

CRITICAL: This data will be sent to 11 external APIs, so format accuracy is essential.

FIELD REQUIREMENTS WITH EXACT FORMATS:

1. **Title**: Clean title for API queries (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
   - Remove line breaks, extra spaces, formatting
   - No HTML tags or special characters  
   - Example: "Effects of Machine Learning on Healthcare Outcomes"

2. **Authors**: API-compatible author list (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
   - Each author as separate string in array
   - Format: "FirstName LastName" or "F. LastName"
   - Clean, no extra punctuation
   - Example: ["John Smith", "M. Johnson", "Sarah Williams"]

3. **DOI**: Standard DOI format for resolution APIs
   - Must start with "10." if present
   - Clean format without URL prefixes
   - Example: "10.1234/journal.2024.001"

4. **Journal**: Clean journal name for database queries
   - Full journal name preferred over abbreviations
   - Remove extra formatting, parentheses
   - Example: "Nature Medicine"

5. **Year**: Numeric format for date filtering
   - 4-digit NUMBER only (not string)
   - Example: 2024

6. **Volume**: Clean number for bibliographic APIs
   - Numbers only, no "Vol." prefix
   - Example: "15"

7. **Issue**: Clean number format
   - Numbers only, no "No." or "Issue" prefix
   - Example: "3"

8. **Pages**: Standard page range for citations
   - Format: "start-end" or single page
   - Example: "123-135" or "45"

9. **PMID**: PubMed ID for medical APIs
   - Numbers only, no "PMID:" prefix
   - Example: "12345678"

10. **PMCID**: PubMed Central ID for open access papers
    - Numbers only, no "PMC" prefix
    - Often appears near PMID in biomedical papers
    - Example: "9876543"

11. **Keywords**: API-compatible keyword list
    - Each keyword as separate string
    - Research-quality terms, no punctuation
    - Example: ["machine learning", "healthcare", "clinical outcomes"]

11. **Abstract**: Complete clean text (HIGHEST PRIORITY)
    - Remove formatting, line breaks, extra spaces
    - Complete sentences, proper punctuation
    - Search thoroughly across ALL pages
    - This is CRITICAL for Semantic Scholar and other APIs

12. **Publisher**: Clean organization name
    - Official publisher name
    - Example: "Elsevier" or "Nature Publishing Group"

ABSTRACT EXTRACTION PRIORITY:
- Look thoroughly across ALL pages for abstract sections
- Extract COMPLETE text, including multiple paragraphs
- Check: Abstract, Summary, Introduction summary paragraphs
- This field is CRITICAL for API enrichment success

Return JSON format:
{
  "Title": "clean title without formatting",
  "Authors": ["Author One", "Author Two"],
  "DOI": "10.xxxx/xxxxx",
  "Journal": "clean journal name", 
  "Year": 2024,
  "Volume": "15",
  "Issue": "3", 
  "Pages": "123-135",
  "Abstract": "complete clean abstract text",
  "Keywords": ["keyword1", "keyword2"],
  "PMID": "12345678",
  "PMCID": "9876543",
  "Publisher": "publisher name"
}

Return null for fields not clearly visible. The Abstract field is MOST IMPORTANT for downstream API success.

extracted_data.Title: Comparison of in-person and synchronous remote musculoskeletal exam using augmented reality and haptics: A pilot study
extracted_data.Abstract: Introduction: Utilization of telemedicine for health care delivery increased rapidly during the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. However, physical examination during telehealth visits remains limited. A novel telerehabilitation system—The Augmented Reality-based Telerehabilitation System with Haptics (ARTESH)—shows promise for performing synchronous, remote musculoskeletal examination. Objective: To assess the potential of ARTESH in remotely examining upper extremity passive range of motion (PROM) and maximum isometric strength (MIS). Design: In this cross-sectional pilot study, we compared the in-person (reference standard) and remote evaluations (ARTESH) of participants’ upper extremity PROM and MIS in 10 shoulder and arm movements. The evaluators were blinded to each other’s results. Setting: Participants underwent in-person evaluations at a Veterans Affairs hospital’s outpatient Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation (PM&R) clinic, and underwent remote examination using ARTESH with the evaluator located at a research lab 30 miles away, connected via a high-speed network. Patients: Fifteen participants with upper extremity pain and/or weakness. Interventions: Not applicable. Main Outcome Measures: Inter-rater agreement between in-person and remote evaluations on 10 PROM and MIS movements and presence/absence of pain with movement was calculated. Results: The highest inter-rater agreements were noted in shoulder abduction and protraction PROM (kappa (κ) = 0.44, confidence interval (CI): −0.1 to 1.0), and in elbow flexion, shoulder abduction, and shoulder protraction MIS (κ = 0.63, CI: 0 to 1.0). Conclusions: This pilot study suggests that synchronous tele-physical examination using the ARTESH system with augmented reality and haptics has the potential to provide enhanced value to existing telemedicine platforms. With the additional technological and procedural improvements and with an adequately powered study, the accuracy of ARTESH-enabled remote tele-physical examinations can be better evaluated.
extracted_data.Publisher: American Academy of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation

data.title: A COMPARISON BETWEEN MOTIVATIONS AND PERSONALITY TRAITS IN RELIGIOUS TOURISTS AND CRUISE SHIP TOURISTS
data.abstract:
The purpose of this paper is to analyze the motivations and the personality traits that characterize tourists who
choose religious travels versus cruises. Participating in the research were 683 Italian tourists (345 males and 338
females, age range 18–63 years); 483 who went to a pilgrimage travel and 200 who chose a cruise ship in the
Mediterranean Sea. Both groups of tourists completed the Travel Motivation Scale and the Big Five
Questionnaire. Results show that different motivations and personality traits characterize the different types of
tourists and, further, that motivations for traveling are predicted by specific —some similar, other divergent—
personality trait

Journal.Title: PM & R : the journal of injury, function, and rehabilitation

AbstractText: Utilization of telemedicine for health care delivery increased rapidly during the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. However, physical examination during telehealth visits remains limited. A novel telerehabilitation system-The Augmented Reality-based Telerehabilitation System with Haptics (ARTESH)-shows promise for performing synchronous, remote musculoskeletal examination.
To assess the potential of ARTESH in remotely examining upper extremity passive range of motion (PROM) and maximum isometric strength (MIS).

In this cross-sectional pilot study, we compared the in-person (reference standard) and remote evaluations (ARTESH) of participants' upper extremity PROM and MIS in 10 shoulder and arm movements. The evaluators were blinded to each other's results.

Participants underwent in-person evaluations at a Veterans Affairs hospital's outpatient Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation (PM&R) clinic, and underwent remote examination using ARTESH with the evaluator located at a research lab 30 miles away, connected via a high-speed network.
Fifteen participants with upper extremity pain and/or weakness.
Inter-rater agreement between in-person and remote evaluations on 10 PROM and MIS movements and presence/absence of pain with movement was calculated.

The highest inter-rater agreements were noted in shoulder abduction and protraction PROM (kappa (κ) = 0.44, confidence interval (CI): -0.1 to 1.0), and in elbow flexion, shoulder abduction, and shoulder protraction MIS (κ = 0.63, CI: 0 to 1.0).

This pilot study suggests that synchronous tele-physical examination using the ARTESH system with augmented reality and haptics has the potential to provide enhanced value to existing telemedicine platforms. With the additional technological and procedural improvements and with an adequately powered study, the accuracy of ARTESH-enabled remote tele-physical examinations can be better evaluated.

journal.title: PM & R : the journal of injury, function, and rehabilitation

data.abstractText:
Introduction

Utilization of telemedicine for health care delivery increased rapidly during the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. However, physical examination during telehealth visits remains limited. A novel telerehabilitation system-The Augmented Reality-based Telerehabilitation System with Haptics (ARTESH)-shows promise for performing synchronous, remote musculoskeletal examination.

Objective

To assess the potential of ARTESH in remotely examining upper extremity passive range of motion (PROM) and maximum isometric strength (MIS).

Design

In this cross-sectional pilot study, we compared the in-person (reference standard) and remote evaluations (ARTESH) of participants' upper extremity PROM and MIS in 10 shoulder and arm movements. The evaluators were blinded to each other's results.

Setting

Participants underwent in-person evaluations at a Veterans Affairs hospital's outpatient Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation (PM&R) clinic, and underwent remote examination using ARTESH with the evaluator located at a research lab 30 miles away, connected via a high-speed network.

Patients

Fifteen participants with upper extremity pain and/or weakness.

Interventions

Not applicable.

Main outcome measures

Inter-rater agreement between in-person and remote evaluations on 10 PROM and MIS movements and presence/absence of pain with movement was calculated.

Results

The highest inter-rater agreements were noted in shoulder abduction and protraction PROM (kappa (κ) = 0.44, confidence interval (CI): -0.1 to 1.0), and in elbow flexion, shoulder abduction, and shoulder protraction MIS (κ = 0.63, CI: 0 to 1.0).

Conclusions

This pilot study suggests that synchronous tele-physical examination using the ARTESH system with augmented reality and haptics has the potential to provide enhanced value to existing telemedicine platforms. With the additional technological and procedural improvements and with an adequately powered study, the accuracy of ARTESH-enabled remote tele-physical examinations can be better evaluated.

consensus_result.Title: Comparison of in-person and synchronous remote musculoskeletal exam using augmented reality and haptics: A pilot study
consensus_result.Abstract: Introduction: Utilization of telemedicine for health care delivery increased rapidly during the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. However, physical examination during telehealth visits remains limited. A novel telerehabilitation system—The Augmented Reality-based Telerehabilitation System with Haptics (ARTESH)—shows promise for performing synchronous, remote musculoskeletal examination. Objective: To assess the potential of ARTESH in remotely examining upper extremity passive range of motion (PROM) and maximum isometric strength (MIS). Design: In this cross-sectional pilot study, we compared the in-person (reference standard) and remote evaluations (ARTESH) of participants' upper extremity PROM and MIS in 10 shoulder and arm movements. The evaluators were blinded to each other's results. Setting: Participants underwent in-person evaluations at a Veterans Affairs hospital's outpatient Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation (PM&R) clinic, and underwent remote examination using ARTESH with the evaluator located at a research lab 30 miles away, connected via a high-speed network. Patients: Fifteen participants with upper extremity pain and/or weakness. Interventions: Not applicable. Main Outcome Measures: Inter-rater agreement between in-person and remote evaluations on 10 PROM and MIS movements and presence/absence of pain with movement was calculated. Results: The highest inter-rater agreements were noted in shoulder abduction and protraction PROM (kappa (κ) = 0.44, confidence interval (CI): −0.1 to 1.0), and in elbow flexion, shoulder abduction, and shoulder protraction MIS (κ = 0.63, CI: 0 to 1.0). Conclusions: This pilot study suggests that synchronous tele-physical examination using the ARTESH system with augmented reality and haptics has the potential to provide enhanced value to existing telemedicine platforms. With the additional technological and procedural improvements and with an adequately powered study, the accuracy of ARTESH-enabled remote tele-physical examinations can be better evaluated.

confidence_factors.reasoning: Vision data used as foundation with strong API validation from multiple sources. Publisher corrected from vision to Crossref/Unpaywall data. Citations and OpenAccess status added from Semantic Scholar and OpenAlex. Year validated as 2023 from most authoritative sources despite some APIs reporting 2022.

api_success_summary.insights: Excellent coherence among major APIs (Crossref, PubMed, Europe PMC, Semantic Scholar, OpenAlex). Core API returned irrelevant article. Most valuable enhancements came from Crossref (publisher, affiliations), Semantic Scholar (citations, OA status), and PubMed (PMID validation).

llm_topics_json.prompt_sent:
You are a scientific research assistant extracting data for academic comparison tables with statistical rigor.

CRITICAL INSTRUCTIONS FOR ACADEMIC COMPARISON:

- SYSTEMATICALLY scan ALL content: text, tables, figures, charts, appendices
- PRIORITIZE quantitative data while preserving qualitative context
- When conflicts exist in the paper, prioritize MOST RECENT/AUTHORITATIVE source
- Extract ALL relevant details mentioned - DON'T truncate important information
- Include statistical tests results (Z-scores, t-values, chi-square, etc.)
- Extract accuracy rates, completion rates, success rates with specific numbers
- Capture comparative data (e.g., "46% vs 27%", "Group A: 64.5%, Group B: 68.2%")
- Use proper numeric format: "p = 0.007" not "p = .007", "81" not "eighty-one"

COMPREHENSIVE CAPTURE REQUIREMENTS:

- List ALL hardware components: cameras, sensors, headsets, controllers, phones, tablets, webcams, probes
- Include ALL software details: platforms, SDKs, libraries, export formats (CSV, JSON), feedback systems
- Capture ALL measurement instruments: scales, questionnaires, assessment tools (SUS, NASA-TLX, FES-I, MoCA, IKDC, VAS, ABC scale, WHODAS 2.0, etc.)
- Note ALL technical specifications: resolutions, frame rates, tracking capabilities, joint counts
- Include ALL study phases: pilot tests, technical validation, user studies, expert evaluations
- Capture ALL procedural details: training time, calibration steps, data export processes, real-time feedback

CONFLICT RESOLUTION:

- If conflicting information exists, prioritize methods/results over abstract
- When uncertain, include both: "X in abstract, Y in methods section"

Extract the following 7 scientific topics:

1. *study_design*: Extract the PRIMARY study type/design using the most specific and authoritative terminology from the paper's methods section. Recognize equivalent terms: "RCT" = "Randomized controlled trial", "Pilot study" = "Feasibility pilot study", "Cross-sectional" = "Observational cross-sectional", "User study" = "User evaluation study". When multiple study type descriptions exist, prioritize the most comprehensive version from methods over abstract. Include specific qualifiers when mentioned (e.g., "multicenter", "double-blind", "waitlist-controlled") as these add valuable detail. Format as brief phrase describing core study methodology, avoiding generic terms like "study" or "research" alone.

2. *methodology*: ONE comprehensive sentence covering: technology + application + key technical details. Include: ALL device models, software platforms, measurement tools, statistical analyses. Capture ALL hardware components mentioned (cameras, sensors, controllers, probes, etc.). Include ALL software features (real-time feedback, data export, tracking capabilities). Mention ALL technical specifications (joint tracking numbers, frame rates, resolutions). Example: "Microsoft HoloLens 2 with HoloAnatomy platform for 3D anatomical procedural visualization using real-time motion tracking of 25 joints with CSV data export and real-time visual feedback".

3. *sample_size*: Format: "X participants/patients" (use paper's exact terminology). Include TOTAL numbers if multiple groups exist. Include ALL test phases: technical tests, pilot studies, user evaluations. Example: "25 total: 23 biomedical students + 2 clinical experts; 50 technical validation readings".

4. *population*: ALL demographic details and characteristics not captured in sample_size. Include age, profession, condition, experience, setting details. Add specific numbers when available. Include recruitment sources and inclusion/exclusion criteria.

5. *primary_outcome*: Include ALL measurement tools, scales, timing, specific metrics, usability criteria (ease of use, realism, anatomical accuracy). List ALL assessment instruments used and functional scales (SUS, NASA-TLX, FES-I, MoCA, IKDC, VAS, ABC scale, WHODAS 2.0, etc.), and evaluation dimensions beyond the primary measures.. Include ALL comparison conditions and timepoints. Example: "Patient understanding via 5-point Likert scale assessed pre/post intervention, plus SUS usability scores and NASA-TLX workload assessment".

6. *key_findings*: PRIORITIZE statistical results with practical implications. Format: "Finding 1: [statistical data + meaning]. Finding 2: [data + context]". Include ALL significant findings, p-values, effect sizes, accuracy rates, comparative data, accuracy measurements (sub-mm, degrees), specific understanding domains (surgical risks, operative steps, recovery), and detailed performance metrics beyond statistical significance. Present ALL questionnaire results, prototype performance, qualitative benefits. Include ALL cost factors, training requirements, implementation details. Capture ALL comparison groups and their specific results. Be comprehensive - capture complete findings picture. Include ALL technical specifications mentioned: accuracy measurements (sub-mm, degrees).

7. *limitations*: Extract ALL limitations from limitation/discussion sections. Include sample size issues, technical equipment requirements, methodological, practical constraints. Mention ALL equipment needs, calibration requirements, manufacturing variability. Include ALL generalizability issues, validity concerns, implementation barriers. Capture training requirements, cost constraints, specialized equipment needs. Note real-world applicability issues and clinical implementation challenges. Don't summarize - capture complete limitation landscape.

Return as valid JSON with this EXACT structure:

{
  "study_design": "string",
  "methodology": "string",
  "sample_size": "string",
  "population": "string",
  "primary_outcome": "string",
  "key_findings": "string",
  "limitations": "string"
}

extracted_topics.population: All male veterans, average age 63 years, with upper extremity pain and/or weakness, recruited from hospital-based PM&R, Physical Therapy, or Occupational Therapy clinics.
extracted_topics.limitations: Small sample size (n = 15) limits generalizability; high-speed Internet required; binary grading of PROM and MIS not clinically accepted; ARTESH system under development and not commercially available.
extracted_topics.methodology: ARTESH system using two Xbox Kinect RGB-D cameras, one haptic controller, a 3D-capable TV, active 3D glasses, and a computer for remote examination of upper extremity strength and ROM with real-time data transmission over high-speed Internet, using Unity game engine for 3D environment rendering.
extracted_topics.key_findings: Finding 1: Highest inter-rater agreements in shoulder abduction and protraction PROM (kappa = 0.44, CI: -0.1 to 1.0). Finding 2: Elbow flexion, shoulder abduction, and shoulder protraction MIS (kappa = 0.63, CI: 0 to 1.0).
extracted_topics.primary_outcome: Inter-rater agreement between in-person and remote evaluations on 10 PROM and MIS movements using kappa statistics with 95% confidence intervals.

raw_openai_response.content:
```json
{
  "study_design": "Cross-sectional pilot study",
  "methodology": "ARTESH system using two Xbox Kinect RGB-D cameras, one haptic controller, a 3D-capable TV, active 3D glasses, and a computer for remote examination of upper extremity strength and ROM with real-time data transmission over high-speed Internet, using Unity game engine for 3D environment rendering.",
  "sample_size": "15 participants",
  "population": "All male veterans, average age 63 years, with upper extremity pain and/or weakness, recruited from hospital-based PM&R, Physical Therapy, or Occupational Therapy clinics.",
  "primary_outcome": "Inter-rater agreement between in-person and remote evaluations on 10 PROM and MIS movements using kappa statistics with 95% confidence intervals.",
  "key_findings": "Finding 1: Highest inter-rater agreements in shoulder abduction and protraction PROM (kappa = 0.44, CI: -0.1 to 1.0). Finding 2: Elbow flexion, shoulder abduction, and shoulder protraction MIS (kappa = 0.63, CI: 0 to 1.0).",
  "limitations": "Small sample size (n = 15) limits generalizability; high-speed Internet required; binary grading of PROM and MIS not clinically accepted; ARTESH system under development and not commercially available."
}
```
